Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of High-Voltage Transmission Electron Microscope

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0958574
Katz

"This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5)."

The University of Missouri, Columbia, proposes to acquire a 300 kV transmission electron microscope (TEM). To meet the needs of a large user group, this microscope will be equipped with the following features: scanning transmission accessory, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, electron energy loss spectroscopy, high-angle annular dark field imaging capability, electron energy loss spectroscopy, energy filtering, cryo stage, and tomography function. The instrument will be housed in the University Electron Microscopy Core Facility (EMC). The director and staff of the EMC will be responsible for maintaining the instrument and for assisting and training users.

This instrument will primarily serve a diverse group of scientists and engineers whose work involves fabrication and characterization of materials at the nanometer scale. For example, one of the research groups that would use the instrument is involved in the fabrication of nanopores that would regulate the permeability of membranes in response to the binding of specific ligands and thus would serve as detectors for the ligands. The instrument will be used to characterize the nanopores and nanopore-ligand interactions. This will aid in the optimization of nanopore-membrane detector design. Other investigators would use the instrument to assist in the development of bioremediation of toxins and pollutants. For example, one research group will use the X-ray spectroscopy feature of the microscope to assess the ability of microorganisms to sequester heavy metal contaminants from water. Finally, some of the researchers will use the instrument to answer basic biological questions, such as the organization of organelles within cells under various conditions. The cryo stage and tomography will be particularly helpful in these types of studies. The EMC will use the instrument and its accessories to train faculty, students, and postdoctoral fellows in the principles of transmission electron microscopy and in the use of the various accessories of the instrument and how these tools can be applied to further their research endeavors. Access to the instrument will enhance training in the many areas where it can be employed to advance investigations that would not otherwise be possible.

Purchase and Installation of the HV-TEM

The high-voltage transmission electron microscope (HV-TEM; Tecnai TF30TWIN - 22402 - Serial #: 9920050) with accessories was purchased from FEI Company, Hillsboro, Oregon, and delivered to the University of Missouri in October 2011. A specialized room (W128) within the University of Missouri (MU) Electron Microscopy (EM) Core Facility was renovated to house the instrument. The instrument and accessories are fully  installed, and testing for operations specifications by the manufacturer's engineer was completed in late May 2012.  During the specifications testing, a small electromagnetic interference that affected the GIF filter was identified and corrected. Final transfer of the instrument from FEI to the University of Missouri was accomplished in late May 2012.  

Management of the HV-TEM

The HV-TEM has been integrated within the MU EM Core, one of several research core facilities administered by the MU Office of Research, under the direction of Robert V. Duncan, PhD, Vice Chancellor for Research. The EM Core provides training and technical expertise on the use of transmission and scanning electron microscopes in the facility. The EM Core also provides educational opportunities through undergraduate and graduate courses focused on the utilization of these technologies. The EM Core technical staff includes an associate director, recently recruited from the National Cancer Institute for her expertise with TEM applications; a facilities manager, with extensive experience in sample preparation and operation of all the microscopes; a materials science expert, with experience in E-beam lithography and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS); and a research technician. A faculty advisory committee, made up of campus users of the EM Core instrumentation, will meet regularly with the staff to set priorities and policies. The operation and maintenance of the HV-TEM, as with the other EM Core instruments, is supported through user fees , maintenance contracts and operational costs of the instruments and ancillary equipment. The user fee schedule is reviewed annually for adjustments to account for cost variations. Any shortfalls in the total operational costs not met by user fees are subsidized by the MU Office of Research.  

 

Training on Use of HV-TEM

Training workshops by the FEI applications specialists for the MU EM Core technical staff were completed in May and June 2012.  Faculty, staff and student users will begin training on use of the microscope. In addition, EM technologies are the focus of three undergraduate and graduate level courses, administered through the Department of Physics and the Department of Veterinary Pathobiology, to provide fundamental theory and training that allows students to expand their breadth of scientific expertise and utilization of these technologies in their research projects.
